snippet.title: ROADM options in optical networks: flexible grid or not?
snippet.description:
ROADM options in optical networks: flexible grid or not?
by Sheryl L. Woodward
"... ﻿ROADM options in optical networks: flexible grid or not? Sheryl L. Woodward AT&T Labs ..."
Abstract \- Add to MetaCart
Abstract: Flexible-grid networks are attractive because they claim greater spectral efficiency and the ability to accommodate future modulation formats that may need wider channel bandwidths. We compare flexible-grid networks to alternative approaches. OCIS codes: (060.0060) Fiber optics and optical communications; (060.4250) Networks 1.

snippet.title: Optical WDM Networks: Traffic Grooming in Mesh Networks and Metro Networks using ROADMs
snippet.description:
Optical WDM Networks: Traffic Grooming in Mesh Networks and Metro Networks using ROADMs
by Hongyue Zhu , 2005
"... Networks and Metro Networks using ROADMs Abstract Optical Fiber technology employing wavelength ..."
Abstract \- Add to MetaCart
Optical Fiber technology employing wavelength-division multiplexing (WDM) has and continues to be investigated and commercially deployed to meet our ever-increasing bandwidth demands. WDM partitions the huge bandwidth of an optical fiber into many non-overlapping wavelength channels, each of which can operate at the data rate of 10 Gbps (or 40 Gbps or higher). This dissertation investigates design and modeling issues of optical WDM mesh networks, as well as ring networks. This dissertation first proposes a novel generic graph model for traffic grooming in heterogeneous WDM mesh networks so that low-speed traffic streams can be “groomed ” (or carried) by high-capacity wavelength channels. This model uses an auxiliary graph to represent the network state, which can accommodate various resource constraints. It can achieve different grooming policies by employing a simple shortest-path algorithm, and it can be applied to both static and dynamic trafficgrooming scenarios. A grooming policy determines how to carry the traffic in a certain situation.

snippet.title: OFC/NFOEC Technical Digest © 2012 OSA On Concentrating Regenerator Sites in ROADM Networks
snippet.description:
OFC/NFOEC Technical Digest © 2012 OSA On Concentrating Regenerator Sites in ROADM Networks
by Balagangadhar G. Bathula, Rakesh K. Sinha, Angela L. Chiu, Mark D. Feuer, Guangzhi Li, Sheryl L. Woodward, Weiyi Zhang, Keren Bergman, Inwoong Kim, Paparao Palacharla
"... ﻿OFC/NFOEC Technical Digest © 2012 OSA On Concentrating Regenerator Sites in ROADM Networks ..."
Abstract \- Add to MetaCart
Abstract: Concentrating optical regenerators in a subset of nodes provides significant savings. We present a heuristic for choosing this subset. In the studied cases our results have 1 or 2 more sites than the minimum. OCIS codes: (060.4256) Networks, network optimization, (060.1155) All-optical networks I.
